author: Kevin Ho
description: Text Generation 2 - In case anyone wants a log line or synopsis idea for a book or film or TV idea. Taking what I did from my first one and adding more layers and text choices to it.
code:
// require /text/tracery.min.js

const storyGrammar = {
  story: [
    "#time#, #year#. It's the year that the #noun# #verb#. It #verb# so fast. #pronoun.capitalize# said #pronoun# had #number# #time2# to get out. #phrase#",
  ],
  phrase: ["We all knew what it meant.", "#question.capitalize# do we leave?"],
  question: ["what", "how", "where", "why"],
  pronoun: ["we", "he", "she", "I", "they"],
  descriptor: ["chaos", "flames", "a void", "nothing", "everything", "infinitely"],
  number: ["two", "four", "thirteen", "twenty-five", "nine", "a few", "some"],
  time2: ["days", "weeks", "months", "years"],
  noun: [
    "pandemic",
    "hurricane",
    "apocalypse",
    "outbreak",
    "invasion",
    "explosion",
    "decimation of #things#",
    "end of #things#",
    "armageddon",
    "annihilation of #things#"
  ],
  things: ["land", "humanity", "culture", "society", "free will", "time"],
  verb: ["started", "happened", "occured", "began", "erupted into #descriptor#"],
  time: [
    "January",
    "February",
    "March",
    "April",
    "May",
    "June",
    "July",
    "August",
    "September",
    "October",
    "November",
    "December",
  ],
  year: [
    "2022",
    "2021",
    "2020",
    "2019",
    "2018",
    "2017",
    "2016",
    "2015",
    "2014",
    "2013",
    "2012",
    "2010",
    "2009",
    "2008",
    "2007",
    "2006",
    "2005",
    "2004",
    "2003",
    "2002",
    "2001",
    "2000",
  ],
  response: [
    "#pronoun.capitalize# didn't know what to do.",
    "What's next?",
    "That's the last #pronoun# saw of us.",
    "#pronoun.capitalize# never asked what happened.",
    "#pronoun.capitalize# faced a choice.",
    "It's #adjective#. #pronoun.capitalize# had no other choice.",
  ],
};

function main() {
  const grammar = tracery.createGrammar(storyGrammar);
  grammar.addModifiers(tracery.baseEngModifiers);
  const story = grammar.flatten("#story#");
  display(story);
  const response = grammar.flatten("#response#");
  display(response);
}

function display(...strings) {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  div.style = "font-size: 25px; margin: 5%; line-height: 1;";
  div.innerText = strings.join("\n");
  document.body.append(div);
}

// tracery doesn't load immediately, not sure why, so kludge it
setTimeout(main, 10);

author: Justin Bakse
description:
This post is surprisingly on brand for the parameters week. Its a pretty nerdy story.
I’d really like to get away with printing those legos I'm working on right on the plate.  The first few layers of a resin print are exposed more heavily to stick to the plate. Because they are over exposed they tend to spread a little bit, making the walls a little thicker on the where they meet the plate: elephant’s foot.
One technique for dealing with this problem is to dim the outer pixels in the burn in layers, and some tools can do this for you but you need to specify parameters for how many pixels to dim, and how much.
This script generates teststrip prints so you can find out EXACTLY what params to use for your specific resin and exposure time.

function main() {
  const grammar = tracery.createGrammar(storyGrammar);
  grammar.addModifiers(tracery.baseEngModifiers);
  story = grammar.flatten("#story#");
  display(story);
}

function display(...strings) {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  div.style =
    "padding: 50px; background: rgb(0,0,0); color: white; font-size: 25px; margin: 5%; line-height: 1.5; font-family: 'Fondamento', cursive;";
  div.innerText = strings.join("\n");
  document.body.append(div);
}

// tracery doesn't load immediately, not sure why, so kludge it
setTimeout(main, 10);

description: I wanted to try using Tweakpane for my second sketch, but this proved to be more complicated than expected. I struggled to get the Tweakpane.Pane() function to work, so ended up copying my code into a sketch I found online for which Tweakpane was working. I was planning on adding fish to the background of this sketch and using noise to animate the movements of the fish, but I instead spent time trying to get Tweakpane working. I also wanted to use variables for all of the shapes I created, rather than hard coding the values in, but this was also taking too long so I stopped.

author: Justin Bakse
description:
Today's sketch. I like this one (certainly more than yesterdays). I was going for an abstract but detailed peacock. Got the tail working. I'm working in a kind of half-planned half-unplanned mode. 

One trick to getting detail is to make a small detailed thing, and then make a medium sized thing out of that, and a large thing out of the medium thing. In this case, i made a 'feather', 'feater ring', and 'tail'.

Times up now, so my bird has no body.

author: Justin Bakse
description:
Make Stuff that Makes Stuff that Makes Stuff?

The code in the image IS the output. I'm using the native js template literals to construct a valid p5.js program using context free grammar.

This is just an opening sketch for a larger experiment i have in mind: generate hundreds of thousands of basic p5.js sketches, run them to generate code->image pairs, then train a ML model on them, ???, profit.

author: Ariel Calver
description:
Challenge Pixel Ouroboros:

I liked the sketch I produced for the pair challenge, so I decided to tweak that code in order to produce this sketch. I uploaded an image I took of tea bags to P5JS and pixel processed the image by playing with StrokeWeight, Noise, and the order of arguments in order to change the color and texture of different quadrants in the image. The colors seem to become more muted over time and the contrast between different colors also seems to decrease

function main() {
  const grammar = tracery.createGrammar(storyGrammar);
  grammar.addModifiers(tracery.baseEngModifiers);
  if(Math.random()<0.5){
     story = grammar.flatten("#storyA#");
  }else{
     story = grammar.flatten("#storyB#");
  }
  
  display(story);
  
}

function display(...strings) {
  const div = document.createElement("div");
  div.style = "padding: 50px; background: black; color: white; font-size: 35px; margin: 5%; line-height: 1.5; font-family:    Playfair Display, Baskerville, serif";
  div.innerText = strings.join("\n");
  document.body.append(div);
}

// tracery doesn't load immediately, not sure why, so kludge it
setTimeout(main, 10);

author: Binna Lee
description:
Week1: Sketch 2: Response to Paridhi's instruction on the Temperature of Emotions. 
While following Paridhi's instructions, I thought it would be great if they specified the three spaces: visualizing emotions, environment, and verbalizing both elements. 

My emotion was quite complex today. There is a loud and energetic Indian Hindu religious ceremony outside my apartment, and the weather is raining with fresh air, and my emotion is lost. Visualizing abstract emotions and mundane weather in detail allowed me to consider the influence of the environment and the state of my mind.

I drew inspiration from Unnati's Dreamland map and a YouTube video on how to generate a basic map in order to generate this fairy land! author: Shuyao X
description: Compute Comp Form content based on the whole book, using Markov Chain in python. The result doesn't make much sense lol
code:
import collections
import random
import re
import numpy as np
import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
import pandas as pd
import time
from string import punctuation


def get_url(keyword):
    url = "https://compform.net/"+keyword
    return url

#grab text from each paragrahs
def get_para(url):
    response = requests.get(url)
    doc = BeautifulSoup(response.text,'html.parser')
    ps = doc.find(class_="container comp-form-copy").find_all("p")

    paras = ''
    for i in ps:
        para = i.text
        paras = paras+para
    return paras

re = requests.get("https://compform.net/")
d = BeautifulSoup(re.text,'html.parser')
wrap = d.find_all(class_="nav-wrap")
wraps = wrap[0:2]

keywords = []
for w in wraps:
    ps = w.find_all("p")
    for p in ps:
        a = p.find('a', href=True)
        if a is not None:
            kw = a['href'].replace('.','')
            keywords.append(kw)


data = []
for k in keywords:
    url = get_url(k)
    paras = get_para(url)
    
    result = {}
    result['text'] = paras
    result['chapter'] = k
    
    time.sleep(3)
    data.append(result)


text = pd.DataFrame(data)

compform = ''
for t in text['text']:
    compform = compform+t


tokenized_text = []
for word in compform.split():
    tokenized_text.append(word.strip(punctuation).lower())


# Create graph.
markov_graph = collections.defaultdict(lambda: collections.Counter())

last_word = tokenized_text[0].lower()
for word in tokenized_text[1:]:
  word = word.lower()
  markov_graph[last_word].update([word])
  last_word = word

def walk_graph(graph, distance=5, start_node=None):

  if distance <= 0:
    return []
  
  # If not given, pick a start node at random.
  if not start_node:
    start_node = random.choice(list(graph.keys()))
  
  weights = np.array(
      list(markov_graph[start_node].values()),
      dtype=np.float64)
  # Normalize word counts to sum to 1.
  weights /= weights.sum()

  # Pick a destination using weighted distribution.
  choices = list(markov_graph[start_node].keys())
  chosen_word = np.random.choice(choices, None, p=weights)
  
  return [chosen_word] + walk_graph(
      graph, distance=distance-1,
      start_node=chosen_word)

for i in range(10):
    print(' '.join(walk_graph(
      markov_graph, distance=20)), '\n')

author: Ariel Calver
description:
I wanted to experiment with randomness and noise and see a comparison between how the two functions work in real time. Originally, I looped the functions so that both of the eyes bounced, but I ultimately thought it would be fun to generate a face from this code, so I added the noLoop() function in at the end. 

One of the eyes was created using 1D Perlin Noise, so it only moves along the horizontal axis every time I generate a new image. The other eye moves to a random location on the canvas every time the image is generated.

I got to play around with the curve() function for the first time here too.

As a fun experiment, hit pause to capture a face!

author: Justin Bakse
description:
This was yesterday's sketch, and it didn't go as planned. I started out wanting to make a snowman. Maybe a sort of fractal snowman? I got something kind working, but I didn't like it much. So I started just "messing it up". And ended up with this kind of tangle. And then pretty quickly, time was up. I've done code-illustrations of vines a few times, and this kind exact of mess is something I've made before, so I wasn't feeling it.

After a night of sleep though, I'm thinking i might try the snowman again, this time mixing turtles and regular p5 calls like ellipse().

comments.comment: Ah, yes. I see it.
